Graphical abstract A series of PEG modified Mn-based catalysts synthesized by precipitation method were surveyed to evaluate their catalytic performances for NO oxidation. At the calcination temperature lower than 500 °C, the Mn-based catalysts are all the crystal structure of γ-MnO2, while other catalysts at calcination temperatures of 600–800 °C possess the crystal structure of Mn2O3. γ-MnO2 exhibits better catalytic behavior for NO oxidation than Mn2O3, and obtains the maximum NO conversion of 93% at 220 °C with a mass space velocity of 48 000 mL g−1 h−1. Compared with Mn2O3, γ-MnO2 also shows better low-temperature performance with the conversion of above 50% at 130 °C, and in a wide temperature span from 130 °C to 380 °C with a mass space velocity of 48 000 mL g−1 h−1. This activity temperature window is even broader than that of some noble metal catalysts. The physico-chemical characteristic was fully analyzed through XRD, BET, SEM, H2-TPR, NO/O2-TPD, XPS, DRIFTS and FT-IR, and the characterization results demonstrate that PEG can lead to an excellent catalytic activity, because it not only increases the surface area of the catalyst, but also enhances the adsorption of O2 and NO at low temperature. Keywords NO oxidation γ-MnO2 Polyethylene glycol mediated synthesis H2O and SO2 poisoning 1 Introduction Nitrogen oxides (NOX) have attracted growing attention from all over the world because they lead to a train of environmental issues such as photochemical smog, acid rain, and ozone depletion [1,2]. NO selective catalytic oxidation (SCO) plays a vital role in many NOX removal technologies, such as “fast” selective catalytic reduction (SCR) [3,4], NOX storage-reduction (NSR) [5,6], and lean NOX trap (LNT) [7,8]. NO SCO technology is a potentially ideal way to reduce the selective catalytic reduction (SCR) cost by decreasing the reaction temperature, and even alters the current NO removal technology. Typically, NO is a water-insoluble gas, and accounts for more than 90% of NOX. Thus, it is of great significance to develop eligible NO oxidation catalysts to oxidize NO into NO2 because NO2 can be easily removed by wet scrubbing method [9], especially for the NO/NOX ratio of about 50–60%, where the optimum removal efficiency is obtained [10]. For NO oxidation, noble metal (e.g. Ag [11,12], Pt [13–15].) catalysts have been extensively researched, but high cost limits their applications. Transition metal based catalysts [16–18], especially Mn-based catalysts, are gaining more and more attentions owing to their high activity and low cost as well as low environmental impact. Wu et al. [19] demonstrated that MnOX/TiO2 composite nano-oxides reach 89% conversion at 250 °C with a GHSV of 25 000 h−1 as the Mn/Ti ratio is 0.3. Wang et al. [20] found mixed-phase catalysts synthesized by co-precipitation method exhibit better low-temperature catalytic performance for NO oxidation than Pt. Li et al. [10] reported that Mn–Co–Ce–Ox catalyst shows marvelous catalytic activities as the temperature is lower than 200 °C. However, most Mn-based catalysts show bad low-temperature performance, even though some of them exhibit high catalytic activity, their activity temperature windows are very narrow. Hence, it is necessary to synthesize catalysts that exhibit high performance at low temperatures and achieve high rates in a wide temperature range. In our previous research [21], four catalysts (α-, β-, γ- and δ-MnO2) were synthesized through hydrothermal method, and the γ-MnO2 catalyst obtains 91% NO conversion at 250 °C with a mass space velocity of 48 000 mL g−1 h−1. Meanwhile, the surfactant polyethylene glycol (PEG) involved in synthesis of catalysts can increase the catalyst surface areas and improve the catalytic activities. Zhao et al. [22] synthesized Ag/white graphene foam catalyst in presence of PEG. This kind of catalyst shows very high efficiency and stability in methanol oxidation, and the T 50 and T 95 of the catalyst are as low as 50 °C and 110 °C. Sonawane et al. [23] reported that the surface morphology and structure of Fe–TiO2 thin films prepared by sol-gel dip coating can be altered by adding PEG, and the hydroxyl content adsorbed by the films increases with the amount of PEG added. Hou et al. [24] used PEG-modified silica to effectively stabilize and immobilize palladium nanoparticles for the selective aerobic oxidation of alcohol using supercritical carbon dioxide as the mobile phase. The catalyst shows excellent activity and stability under continuous operation condition. Thus, the catalytic properties of Mn-based catalysts might be potentially further improved by the effect of PEG. In this study, Mn-based catalysts were synthesized by precipitation method, and their performances for NO oxidation were investigated. The factors dominating the catalytic properties of Mn-based catalysts were analyzed by a series of characterization methods, including X-ray diffraction (XRD), N2 adsorption, scanning electron microscopy (SEM), temperature-programmed reduction by H2 (H2-TPR), NO temperature-programmed desorption (NO-TPD), O2 temperature-programmed desorption (O2-TPD), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) and Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectrometry. Besides, the effects of SO2 and H2O on the catalyst were also investigated as SO2 and H2O are usually present in the exhaust. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of catalysts All chemical reagents were of analytical grade and used as received without further purification. Deionized water was employed to prepare the solutions used in the study. Mn-based catalysts were synthesized by precipitation method. Two solutions were prepared for synthesizing the catalysts, which consisted of the following components: Solution I: 2.8475 g of KMnO4, 0.5 mL of concentrated HNO3, in 200 mL of deionized water. Solution II: 9.6633 g of 50% solution of Mn(NO3)2, 0.5 mL of concentrated HNO3 and 1.02 g of PEG (when used), in 200 mL of deionized water. To form homogeneous solutions, solution I and II were separately magnetically stirred for 30 min. After Solution I was gradually added to Solution II with stirring, the mixture was continuously stirred in a 500 mL of beaker for 6 h and then a precipitate was obtained and filtered by a Buchner funnel. The above precipitate was washed with deionized water three times, dried in a vacuum oven at 80 °C for 10 h, and subsequently calcined at 200–800 °C for 2 h in air to obtain different Mn-based catalysts. The Mn-based catalysts were denoted as Mn-200, Mn-300, Mn-400, Mn-500, Mn-600, Mn-700, and Mn-800 according to their calcination temperatures. The catalyst without PEG addition was also synthesized, which was calcined at 300 °C and denoted as Mn-noPEG-300. 2.2 Characterization XRD patterns of catalysts were recorded by a D/max2500 diffractometer (Rigaku, Japan) using Cu-Kα radiation operated at a voltage of 40 kV and a current of 15 mA with a scanning rate of 8°/min. The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface areas and pore size distribution were determined using an ASAP 2460 (Micrometrics) at −196 °C. Prior to the measurements, the samples were outgassed at 200 °C for 3 h. SEM observations were conducted on a scanning electron microscope (TESCAN Mira3 LMH) was used to analyze the morphology and size of the catalysts. H2-TPR was carried out in an AutoChem II 2920 apparatus according to following steps. The sample (27 mg) was pre-treated in Ar at 200 °C for 30 min. After cooling to 40 °C, the sample was heated to 800 °C at 10 °C min−1 in 10 vol% H2 (Ar balance) with a flow rate of 40 mL min−1. A thermal conductivity detector (TCD) was used to monitor hydrogen consumption. TPD was performed in an AutoChem II 2920 apparatus for O2-TPD (AMI-300HP for NO-TPD) according to the following steps. The sample (about 950 mg) was treated in Ar at 200 °C for 60 min. After cooling down the samples to ambient temperature, the gas was switched to O2 for 1 h (2.5% NO/N2 for 0.5 h) and then blew with Ar at 40 mL min−1 for 30 min. Subsequently, TPD operation was performed at a ramping rate of 10 °C min−1 to 800 °C in Ar (40 mL min−1). A TCD was applied to detected desorption of O2 (NO). XPS data were acquired on an ESCALab 250Xi electron spectrometer using Mg K radiation (1253.6 eV). Binding energies were calibrated relative to the C1 s peak from carbon contamination at 284.6 eV. DRIFTS data were obtained by Nicolet 6700. The sample was pretreated at 300 °C in N2 for 1 h. After cooling to 220 °C, the sample was exposed to 500 ppm NO, 5% O2 (N2 balance) and the DRIFTS spectra were recorded. Finally, the catalyst was purged for 20 min with N2 at 220 °C. FT-IR spectra of the catalysts were recorded with a Bruker VERTEX70 spectrometer in KBr disks at 8 cm−1 resolution. 2.3 Activity test A fixed-bed quartz tubular reactor (i.d. 8 mm), as described in our previous study [21], was used to evaluate the NO oxidation activity of Mn-based catalysts under atmospheric pressure. After placing 0.500 g of the catalyst (40–60 mesh) in the centre of the reactor, the mixed gases (500 ppm NO, 5 vol% O2, N2 balance, 400 mL min−1, corresponding to a GHSV of 48 000 mL g−1 h−1) were introduced for 90 min at ambient temperature. Then the catalyst was heated to the required temperature at a heating rate of 5 °C min−1, and maintained for 30 min (90 min for 100 °C). The effects of O2 concentration and flow rate on NO oxidation were investigated. Additionally, both 10 vol% H2O and 200 ppm SO2 were also applied to study the performance of Mn-based catalysts. The inlet and outlet NOX concentrations were measured by a KM-9106 flue gas analyzer (KANE). NO conversion is defined as: NOConversion = (NOin − NOout)/NOin × 100%. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structural characterization Fig. 1 shows the XRD patterns of the catalysts to determine the crystalline phases, and the data reveal that there are only two crystallite phases in the catalyst. At the calcination temperature lower than 500 °C, XRD patterns indicate that the lattice constants of the sample keep the same values of γ-MnO2 (JCPDS 14-0644). Besides, the pattern of Mn-noPEG-300 is consistent with that of γ-MnO2, which illustrates the addition of PEG does not change the crystal form. γ-MnO2 consists of randomly intergrown pyrolusite and ramsdellite [25], so the perfect single crystal is difficult to form. For this reason, the widths and intensities of the diffraction peaks for all MnO2 are significantly widened and lowered. However, when the calcination temperature reaches 500 °C, besides the characteristic peaks of γ-MnO2, three weak diffraction peaks at around 32.9°, 38.2° and 55.1° are observed, which are ascribed to the characteristics of Mn2O3 (JCPDS 71-0636). Obviously, the manganese oxidation states change from γ-MnO2 to Mn2O3 with the increment of calcination temperature. As the calcination temperature increases further, the intensive and sharp diffractions of the catalysts appear at 2θ = 23.1°, 32.9°, 38.2°, 45.1°, 49.3°, 55.1° and 65.7°, agreeing well with the identification cards of Mn2O3 (JCPDS 71-0636). It is clear that the crystallinity of Mn2O3 increases with the rise of calcination temperature from 600 °C to 800 °C. Table 1 summarizes the BET specific surface area, pore size and pore volume of the different catalysts. The surface area of Mn-200 is 199 m2 g−1. As the calcining temperature increases from 200 °C to 500 °C, the surface area of the catalysts decreases gradually. Once the calcining temperature rises above 500 °C, the surface area of these catalysts drops dramatically, even to only 6 m2 g−1 at the calcination temperature of 800 °C. Moreover, the pore volume of the catalysts decreases gradually with the increment of calcination temperature. Compared with Mn-noPEG-300, Mn-300 shows a slightly larger surface area, but it has quite different pore size and pore volume from Mn-noPEG-300, which indicates that the surfactant PEG can facilitate the interactions of active materials [10] and alter the surface structures of the catalysts. N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms of the catalysts are shown in Fig. 2 (a). The isotherms of all catalysts show a characteristic of type IV isotherm pattern. The catalyst without PEG modification has a hysteresis loop of type H2, while the rest of catalysts modified with PEG exhibit type H3 hysteresis loops, implying the irregular pore structure with flake grains or narrow slit-like shapes. When the calcination temperature is above 500 °C, the N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms change remarkably. There may be two explanations for this phenomenon: one is due to the poor pore structure of Mn2O3; another is because of the sintering of catalysts testified by the following results of SEM. The BJH method was used to analyze the corresponding average pore size distributions, as illustrated in Fig. 2(b). Mesopore with the pore diameter of 2–20 nm in the catalysts of Mn-200, Mn-300,and Mn-400 can provide its most pore volume. With the increment of calcination temperature, the pore volume of these PEG-modified Mn-based catalysts decrease gradually, and the centre of their pore size distributions shifts to larger value. The pore size distribution of Mn-600 is between 10 nm to 100 nm. However, when the calcination temperature continues to increase from 600 °C to 800 °C, the surface area and pore volume of these catalysts becomes smaller, and their pore size distributions are almost invisible. Obviously, the average pore size distribution of Mn-noPEG-300 is sharp, centered at about 3.5 nm, while the distribution of Mn-300 becomes wider centered at about 5.5 nm, further demonstrating that PEG can change the texture property of the catalyst. The SEM observations of all Mn-based catalysts were conducted to illustrate their morphologies. As seen from Fig. 3 , Mn-200, Mn-300 and Mn-400 have highly similar characteristics, which are like cobweb-structured cladding particles. As the calcination temperature rises from 500 °C to 600 °C, the network structure surface changes into small solid particles. The increment of calcination temperature promotes the formation of clusters, and the catalyst’s surface turns into less wrinkled structure. Mn-800 is composed of nanorods (about 100 nm in diameter) with a very smooth surface. Mn-500′s milling surface micro-topography is between Mn-400′s and Mn-600′s. These results coincide with the analyses of XRD and BET. As is shown in Fig. 3(h), the surface of Mn-noPEG-300 consists of interweaving curved nanoflakes of 10–20 nm in width, which is very different from that of Mn-300, further illustrating that the morphology of the Mn-based catalyst can be changed by PEG. 3.2 Catalytic performance of catalysts Results on NO conversion over different Mn-based catalysts are given as a function of temperature in Fig. 4 . NO catalytic oxidation is an exothermic reaction, so the NO conversion rises first to the maximum with the reaction temperature rising; nevertheless, as the reaction temperature continues to increase, the NO conversion drops, which may be due to the accelerated NO2 decomposition. As a consequence, each temperature–conversion curve is a typical parabola curve, which is similar to other catalysts’ [16,26,27]. There is no significant difference in the NO conversion among Mn-200, Mn-300, and Mn-400; the maximum NO conversion achieves 93% at around 220 °C; meanwhile, the three catalysts exhibit very good low-temperature performance with the conversion of above 50% at 130 °C. From the previous result of BET specific surface area (Table 1), Mn-200, Mn-300, and Mn-400 have different surface areas, and Mn-200′s surface area is 40 m2 larger than Mn-300′s. However, the NO conversion is very close to each other, which suggests that the surface area is much enough for NO oxidation under this condition. When the calcination temperature is 500 °C, the reaction temperature of the maximum conversion (about 91%) increases to 240 °C, and the conversion declines by 10% as the temperature is lower than 200 °C. As the calcination temperature reaches 600 °C or higher, the NO conversion drops rapidly. At the calcination temperature of 800 °C, the maximum NO conversion is just 47% at 360 °C. Obviously, the Mn-600, Mn-700 and Mn-800 need higher temperatures to achieve conversions near the equilibrium because these catalysts exhibit worse catalytic activity than Mn-200, Mn-300 and Mn-400. Hence, their peak temperatures increase. To sum up, the catalysts with the phase structure of γ-MnO2 indicate better catalytic performances than the catalysts with the crystal structure of Mn2O3. As we all know, properties are usually determined by structure in material world, so the catalytic activity may be influenced by phase structures of the catalyst. The particular tunnel structure of γ-MnO2 determines that catalyst with the structure of γ-MnO2 possesses massive vacancies and point defects (Fig. S1), and thus may lead to an excellent catalytic performance for NO oxidation. The catalytic performance of the catalyst without PEG modification was also tested. It can be found that the activity of the catalyst is promoted by the addition of PEG and the reaction temperature for the maximum NO conversion shifts to the lower temperature. Moreover, NO conversion can keep above 50% in a temperature span of about 250 °C (from 130 to 380 °C) when the calcination temperatures of the catalysts are less than 400 °C. On the basis of characterization results obtained from XRD and SEM, Mn-200, Mn-300 and Mn-400 possess the structure of γ-MnO2, and it can also be concluded from Fig. 4 that there is no obvious difference in the NO conversion among the three catalysts. Thus, Mn-300 is chosen as the NO oxidation catalyst for further study. As shown in Fig. S2, the catalytic stability of Mn-300 was investigated at 220 °C with a mass space velocity of 48 000 mL g−1 h−1, and there is no remarkable decrease in NO conversion with continuous oxidation reaction lasting for 66 h, implying that the Mn-300 shows stable catalytic activity. Moreover, the typical XRD peaks still exist in the used catalyst, and little difference in the intensities of the diffraction peaks between the fresh and used catalysts is observed (Fig. S3). All these results indicate that the crystal phase of the Mn-300 catalyst remains unchanged after reaction, further illustrating the good stability of the catalyst. In order to further observe the good catalyst activity of Mn-300, a comparative analysis for the NO oxidation activity of different catalysts is shown in Table 2 . The catalyst of Mn-300 shows the widest temperature range among the non-noble metal based catalysts reported in the literatures as far as we know. Moreover, Mn-300 exhibits better activity than some noble metal based catalysts [28,29], or demonstrates comparable activity to the Pt/Al2O3 catalyst [30]. In conclusion, Mn-300 synthesized via one-step precipitation shows the widest temperature range and better low-temperature performance, so it has a good application prospect. 3.3 H2-TPR Fig. 5 illustrates H2-TPR profiles of the catalysts to study the redox property. As indicated in Fig. 5(a), two reduction peaks are detected at around 290 °C and 390 °C for Mn-200, Mn-300, and Mn-400, and green powders are observed obviously after H2-TPR experiment, demonstrating manganese monoxide (MnO) is the major reduction product. Mn-500 has similar H2-TPR profile to Mn-300, but the two reduction peaks shift slightly to higher temperatures at 295 °C and 391 °C. Compared with Mn-300, Mn-noPEG-300 shows two reduction peaks at lower temperatures of 278 °C and 361 °C. For Mn-200, Mn-300, Mn-400, Mn-500, and Mn-noPEG-300, the area ratio of the peak at the lower temperature to the one at the higher temperature is about 2:1, which is a typical feature of the reduction of MnO2. The peak at the lower temperature should be attributed to the conversion of MnO2 to Mn3O4, and another appearing at the higher temperature may be ascribed to the conversion of Mn3O4 to MnO [37,38]. However, the H2-TPR profile of Mn-600 and Mn-700 is greatly different from that of Mn-300. The two reduction peaks of Mn-600 appear at 343 °C and 427 °C, and two peaks of Mn-700 are located at 380 °C and 456 °C. For Mn-600 and Mn-700, the area ratio of the peak at the lower temperature to the one at the higher temperature is about 1:2, which is related to the sequential reduction reactions of Mn2O3 → Mn3O4 → MnO [39,40]. Only one reduction peak is observed for Mn-800, which may be resulted from the overlapping of the two reduction peaks. Consequently, increasing calcination temperature not only shifts the reduction peak from lower temperature to higher temperature, but also narrows the gap between the two peaks. As is shown in Fig. 5(b), the initial reduction temperature of Mn-300 is the lowest among all the catalysts, which indicates Mn-300 has the highest mobile oxygen species both at its surface and in its bulk. Compared with Mn-noPEG-300, Mn-300 also has lower initial reduction temperature, which further illustrates that the addition of PEG is able to improve low-temperature redox ability of the catalyst. Generally, the higher oxygen mobility is related to the more adsorbed oxygen, which is further converted to active oxygen responsible for the reaction of NO oxidation, so Mn-300 has the highest catalytic activity. 3.4 NO-TPD The reversibility of NO adsorption was analyzed by the NO-TPD experiment. As shown in Fig. 6 , NO desorption on Mn-based catalysts is observed when the temperature increases from 40 °C to 400 °C. The low-temperature desorption peak (<300 °C) belongs to monodentate nitrate and bridged nitrate, and the high-temperature (300−400 °C) desorption peak is assigned to bidentate nitrate and bridged nitrate [41,42]. However, the initial desorption temperatures are in the order: Mn–500 < Mn–400 < Mn–200 < Mn-300. This sequence is not consistent with the trend of the catalytic activity shown in Fig. 4, implying that the adsorption of NO is not the sole factor that influences the property of NO oxidation. As the calcination temperature is over 600 °C, the adsorption of NO on the catalysts is very little, which is due to the small surface area and the crystal form of the catalysts. Meanwhile, there is no peak appearing between 400 °C to 500 °C, which further demonstrates that Mn-600, Mn-700 and Mn-800 are pure Mn2O3 (Fig. 1). In addition, comparison of the curve of Mn-300 with that of Mn-noPEG-300 shows that the addition of PEG shifts the peaks to lower temperatures, because the PEG affects the structures of the catalysts that further influence the adsorption of nitric oxide. 3.5 O2-TPD To further investigate the oxygen species on the catalysts, the O2-TPD experiments were conducted. In general, the oxygen desorption peak observed in the TPD profile can be ascribed to three kinds of active oxygen species: (i) the low-temperature (LT) desorption peak located at less than 400 °C is assigned to the physically and surface chemically adsorbed oxygen; (ii) the medium-temperature (MT) peak at 400–600 °C is related to the surface lattice oxygen; (iii) the high-temperature (HT) peak appearing at 600 °C is due to the bulk lattice oxygen [43–45]. As is shown in Fig. 7 , similar curves occur for Mn-200, Mn-300 and Mn-400, and Mn-300 has the biggest LT peak. With increasing calcining temperature from 500 °C to 800 °C, the intensity of oxygen desorption peaks of the catalysts decreases markedly, especially for Mn-800, of which LT and MT peaks are hardly detectable. The results indicate that Mn-300 has more physically adsorbed oxygen, chemically adsorbed oxygen and surface lattice oxygen. Moreover, comparison of Mn-300 and Mn-noPEG-300 shows that the addition of PEG shifts the peaks to lower temperature, that is, affects the adsorbed oxygen by changing the structure of the catalysts as described in the previous results of N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms (Fig. 2) and SEM (Fig. 3). 3.6 XPS analysis The XPS analysis was performed to gain insight into the surface chemical states of Mn and O, and the results are displayed in Fig. 8 . The valence states of manganese are usually determined by the location of Mn 2p, and it is also known that the position of Mn 2p3/2 are assigned to Mn4+ (642.2–643.0 eV) [21,46], and Mn3+ (641.3–641.7 eV) [47–49]. As shown in Fig. 8(a), the strong peak of Mn 2p3/2 in the catalysts whose calcinations temperature is not above 500 °C are observed at 642.3 eV, demonstrating that the main manganese in these catalysts (Mn-200, Mn-300, Mn-400 and Mn-500) is Mn4+. However, the Mn 2p3/2 peak appears at 641.3 eV as the calcinations temperature of the catalysts is ranging from 600 °C to 800 °C, and this result indicates that Mn3+ is the main existing form of manganese in the catalysts of Mn-600, Mn-700 and Mn-800. Besides, the Mn 2p3/2 peak in the Mn-noPEG-300 catalyst still appears at 642.3 eV, further indicating that PEG has no effect on the valence states of manganese. As is well known, Mn4+ plays a promoting role in the oxidation reaction of NO to NO2 [48,50,51], and thus probably leads to the better catalytic activity of the Mn-based catalysts whose calcinations temperature is not above 500 °C. Fig. 8(b) illustrates the XPS spectra of O 1 s in the Mn-based catalysts, and there are two O 1s peaks located at 531.4–532.0 eV and 529.5–530.0 eV, which are assigned to the surface chemisorbed oxygen (denoted as Oα) and the lattice oxygen (denoted as Oβ) [47,52], respectively. It is well-recognized that the surface chemisorbed oxygen Oα is an active oxygen species, and plays a promoting role in the NO oxidation reaction due to its higher mobility than lattice oxygen Oβ [33,53]. Therefore, the molar ratios of Oα/Oβ were calculated, and the results are summarized in Table 3 . The order of Oα/Oβ ratio is shown as the following: Mn-200 (0.30) ≈ Mn-300 (0.29) = Mn-400 (0.29) > Mn-500 (0.24) ≈ Mn-noPEG-300 (0.22) > Mn-600 (0.13) > Mn-700 (0.10) > Mn-800 (0.05), and this changing trend is in good agreement with that of the catalytic activities for NO oxidation among these Mn-based catalysts. Hence, it is demonstrated that the catalytic activity is closely related to the surface concentration of Oα species. 3.7 DRIFTS study on NO oxidation The in-situ DRIFTS curves of Mn-300 catalyst during reaction between O2 and NO at 220 °C were obtained. As shown in Fig. 9 , there are three main types of nitrate on the surface of Mn-300. The bands at 1500, 1470 and 1273 cm−1 are due to monodentate nitrate, the bands at 1589 and 1547 cm−1 are attributed to bidentate nitrate, and the bands at 1631 and 1220 cm−1 are ascribed to bridged nitrate [54–57]. The bands at 1913 and 1843 cm−1 associated with typical of nitrosyls [20,58] grow gradually (Fig. S4), manifesting NO is adsorbed on the surface of catalyst. It can be concluded that NO is adsorbed on the catalysts, and then the adsorbed NO is oxidized readily to nitrate species by the chemisorbed oxygen or lattice oxygen [36]; meanwhile the consumed chemisorbed oxygen or lattice oxygen is compensated by gaseous O2. After N2 purging for 20 min at 220 °C, significant decline in the intensities of all the bands demonstrates that the adsorbed nitrate species, the key reaction intermediates in NO oxidation, are easily decomposed to NO2, which is then desorbed from the surface of the catalyst. As a result, the NO oxidation over Mn-300 occurs via an initial adsorption on the catalyst followed by further oxidation to form nitrates and the decomposition of the nitrates into NO2. 3.8 Effect of H2O and SO2 over Mn-300 Since H2O and SO2 always exist in the exhaust, thus the influences of H2O and SO2 on the catalytic performance of Mn-300 were investigated. As shown in Fig. 10 , when 10% H2O is added to the reaction gas, the NO conversion over Mn-300 rapidly decreases to about 75% in 60 min, and Mn-300′s catalytic activity recovers entirely after H2O is removed. The result of reversible deactivation is coincident with that in the literature [10]. When 400 ppm of SO2 is added, NO conversion decreases slightly from 93% to 85% within 60 min, and then it decreases sharply. However, NO conversion can’t be resumed at all even SO2 is removed, which is quite different from the former researches [53]. When both SO2 and H2O are added to the reaction gas, NO conversion descends from 93% to 81% in the first 30 min, which is consistent with the case for the addition of H2O, and then NO conversion decreases down to 51%. After SO2 and H2O are cut off, NO conversion is restored quickly to 70%. As SO2 and H2O co-exist in the feed gas, NO conversion is higher than that under the condition of sole SO2 addition at 150 min. About 30 min after H2O/SO2 and SO2 are cut off, NO conversion of 70% (both H2O and SO2) is much higher than that of 29% (only SO2). As a result, the addition of H2O can prolong the activity of catalysts to a certain degree, which is probably because of the competitive adsorption between H2O and SO2. The influence of H2O and SO2 on the activity of Mn-300 catalyst is illustrated by the FT-IR spectra. As is shown in Fig. 11 , two bands are observed at 3430 and 1631 cm−1 in all curves, which are attributed to the stretching vibration and distorting vibration of OH ground, respectively. And the band at 1051 cm−1 is commonly ascribed to the OH bending vibrations combined with Mn atoms [59]. Moreover, the bands at 520, 574 and 720 cm−1 are the contribution of the stretching vibration of Mn–O and Mn–O–Mn bonds in [MnO6] octahedral [37,60], which further testifies the formation of MnO2. The catalyst after reaction only in the presence of H2O shows a quite similar spectrum to that of the fresh one. However, when SO2 or SO2 + H2O add in, there is a new band observed at 1120 cm−1 in the curve 3 and 4, which can be assigned to SO4 2− [61]. Thus, the addition of SO2 can result in irreversible deactivation because the formation of metal sulfates consumes the active sites of the catalyst [33]. 4 Conclusions In this work, the catalytic performance of PEG-modified Mn-based catalysts prepared by precipitation was investigated, and the catalyst calcined at 300 °C with the crystal structure of γ-MnO2 (denoted as Mn-300) exhibits higher activity than other catalysts. On the Mn-300 catalyst, the maximum NO conversion reaches 93% at 220 °C and keeps above 50% from 130 °C to 380 °C with a mass space velocity of 48 000 mL g−1 h−1, so Mn-300 exhibits good low-temperature performance. The modification of PEG can change the structure of the catalyst, which is beneficial for the increment of the surface area and results in a high adsorption capacity for NO and O2 at low temperature. Mn-300 with the crystal structure of γ-MnO2 leads to abundant mobile oxygen species both at the surface and in the bulk. Therefore, Mn-300 shows good catalytic activity at low temperature. DRIFTS results reveal the NO oxidation mechanism. Both H2O and SO2 exert negative effects on the catalytic activity of Mn-300, but SO2 inhibit its activity irreversibly, which may be due to the formation of metal sulfates that can consume active sites. coredata.dc:description: A series of PEG modified Mn-based catalysts synthesized by precipitation method were surveyed to evaluate their catalytic performances for NO oxidation. At the calcination temperature lower than 500 °C, the Mn-based catalysts are all the crystal structure of γ-MnO2, while other catalysts at calcination temperatures of 600–800 °C possess the crystal structure of Mn2O3. γ-MnO2 exhibits better catalytic behavior for NO oxidation than Mn2O3, and obtains the maximum NO conversion of 93% at 220 °C with a mass space velocity of 48 000 mL g−1 h−1. Compared with Mn2O3, γ-MnO2 also shows better low-temperature performance with the conversion of above 50% at 130 °C, and in a wide temperature span from 130 °C to 380 °C with a mass space velocity of 48 000 mL g−1 h−1. This activity temperature window is even broader than that of some noble metal catalysts. The physico-chemical characteristic was fully analyzed through XRD, BET, SEM, H2-TPR, NO/O2-TPD, XPS, DRIFTS and FT-IR, and the characterization results demonstrate that PEG can lead to an excellent catalytic activity, because it not only increases the surface area of the catalyst, but also enhances the adsorption of O2 and NO at low temperature.
coredata.dc:title: High catalytic activity of Mn-based catalyst in NO oxidation at low temperature and over a wide temperature span
